topics.title: Cold open: prototyping, NLX, and Copilot vs Cursor
topics.summary: Quick teaser clips preview Aparna’s views on AI prototyping, natural language interfaces (NLX), and a coming discussion about Microsoft’s positioning in AI coding tools versus fast-growing newcomers like Cursor.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Aparna’s background (Microsoft CPO, ex-Robinhood/Google) and previews key topics: enterprise product building, agents, coding, PM’s future, and NLX.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Eppo (experimentation platform) and Pragmatic Institute (product training/certifications).

topics.title: Stand-up comedy as product iteration training
topics.summary: Aparna shares her stand-up comedy practice and connects it to product building: rapid iteration cycles, live user feedback, resilience, and “punchline-market fit.”

topics.title: Consumer vs enterprise: governance and change management
topics.summary: Aparna contrasts consumer product work with enterprise: every feature must balance usability with governance/security, and adoption is constrained by slow-changing habits even as AI cycles accelerate.

topics.title: Frontier program: operationalizing “living in the future”
topics.summary: She describes Microsoft’s Frontier approach: letting early adopters use cutting-edge, rough-edge AI features via a “fake company” sandbox to experience “one year in the future” without blocking broader enterprise rollout needs.

topics.title: What agents are: autonomy, complexity, natural interaction
topics.summary: Aparna frames agents pragmatically as tools on a spectrum: more autonomous delegation, handling multi-step complex tasks, and enabling more natural interaction (including async work and richer collaboration).

topics.title: NLX is the new UX: designing conversations
topics.summary: They discuss natural language as an interface that still requires design: prompts as UI elements, editable plans, showing work/progress, follow-ups, and personalization tradeoffs between verbosity and trust.

topics.title: How product development changes: prototypes, taste, coding
topics.summary: Aparna argues teams must prototype constantly (“prompt sets are the new PRDs”), expect faster time-to-demo but longer time-to-deploy, and rely on strong editorial taste to avoid “Frankenstein products”; she also rejects “coding is dead.”

topics.title: PM’s future: less process, more taste and editing
topics.summary: They explore how AI shifts PM value from process to judgment: with idea/prototype supply exploding, PMs must earn authority through taste-making and prioritization while enabling more cross-functional idea generation.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda and how Lenny uses it to run the podcast and community workflows.

topics.title: Reflexive AI usage: the new-tab AI reminder
topics.summary: Aparna explains her self-built Chrome new-tab reminder (“How can you use AI right now?”), why updating priors about AI capability is hard, and how pushing expectations creates an adoption advantage.

topics.title: Leadership lessons: Sundar vs Satya
topics.summary: Aparna compares Sundar Pichai’s calm ecosystem navigation with Satya Nadella’s learning appetite and ability to operate at multiple zoom levels, sharing what she’s learned from both.

topics.title: Counterintuitive product lessons: solve before scale
topics.summary: She argues zero-to-one requires embracing apparent chaos and avoiding premature scaling; metrics can be misleading early, so teams should focus on nailing a few core use cases before claiming broad capability.

topics.title: Zero-to-one “why now” framework: 2 of 3 inflections
topics.summary: Aparna’s framework for new categories: look for at least two of three inflection points—tech step-change, consumer behavior shift, and business model shift—illustrated with Google Lens, Robinhood, and AI monetization models.

topics.title: Hot seat: Microsoft, Copilot, and AI coding tools
topics.summary: Lenny challenges why Cursor and others grew so fast despite Microsoft’s head start; Aparna reframes GitHub Copilot as part of a broader developer system (repo + context + multiple agentic features) rather than a single point product.
